awd_titl_txt: Polar Literacy: A model for youth engagement and learning
awd_abstract_narration:
Polar Literacy: A model for youth engagement and learning will foster public engagement with polar science.  The project targets middle-school aged underserved youth and polar research scientists, with the goal to increase youth interest in and understanding of Polar Regions, and to hone researchers' science communication skills. The project will develop affordable and replicable ways of bringing polar education to informal learning environments, extend our understanding of how polar education initiatives can be delivered to youth with maximum effect, and design a professional development model to improve the capacity for Polar Region researchers to craft meaningful broader impact activities. Polar Literacy will create and test a model which combines direct participation by scientists in after-school settings, with the use of curated polar research data sets and data visualization tools to create participatory learning experiences for youth.  Beyond the life of the project funding, many of the project deliverables (including kits, videos, and other resources) will continue to be used and disseminated online and in person through ongoing work of project collaborators.

Polar Literacy: A model for youth engagement and learning will advance the understanding of informal learning environments while leveraging the rich interdisciplinary resources from polar investments made by the National Science Foundation (NSF). The project's key audiences -- polar researchers, informal educators, and out-of-school time (OST) youth in grades 4-7 (ages 9-13) -- will connect through both place-based and internet-based experiences and work collaboratively to generate a flexible, scalable, and transferable education model. The project will 1) design OST kits and resource guides (focused on Polar Literacy Principles) and include "Concept in a Minute" videos designed to highlight enduring ideas, 2) provide professional development for informal educators, 3) synthesize a club model through adaptation of successful facets of existing informal learning programs, and 4) create Data Jam events for the OST Special Interest (SPIN) clubs and camp programs by modifying an existing formal education model.  A research design, implemented at four nodes over three years, will answer three research questions to evaluate the impact of professional development on informal educators, as well as the impact of programs on youth, and the effectiveness of the model.  In addition to the project team and collaborators who are informal education practitioners, an advisory board composed of experts in youth programming, informal education, and evaluation will guide the project to ensure that it advances the body of informal STEM learning research.  

Polar Literacy is an Advancing Informal STEM Learning (AISL) Innovations in Development project in response to the Dear Colleague Letter: Support for Engaging Students and the Public in Polar Research (NSF 18-103).  Polar Literacy is funded by the Advancing Informal STEM Learning (AISL) program, which seeks to advance new approaches to, and evidence-based understanding of, the design and development of STEM (Science, Technology, Engineering, Mathematics) learning in informal environments. This includes providing multiple pathways for broadening access to and engagement in STEM learning experiences, advancing innovative research on and assessment of STEM learning in informal environments, and developing understandings of deeper learning by participants. This project has co-funding support from the Antarctic section of the Office of Polar Programs.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The Polar Literacy (PL) project focused on extending our understanding of how polar educational interventions can be delivered to youth in informal or Out of School Time (OST) learning environments. Our research questions explore to what extent we can create OST sessions focused on polar literacy concepts and data that youth find engaging.  We focused on increasing: 1) youth polar knowledge using the Polar Literacy Principles (PLP); 2) STEM identity in youth including their engagement and fascination with science; 3) youth data skills using polar data; 4) the capacity of early career scientist collaborators to create effective broader impacts; and 5) youth engagement in climate change education using a polar theme. 

 

Much of this work took place during the COVID pandemic. We worked with 1,581 youth (grades 5-12) over four years in 22 states. For participants for whom we had demographic data, a large majority (71%) were members of Underrepresented Minority (URM) groups and the majority (56%) were identified by parents as female.

 

The Polar Literacy project produced five deliverables:

1. Polar Adventure: A series of online explorations (https://polar-ice.org/polar-explorer-adventures/) highlight the research of nine polar researchers. Youth are engaged in learning about the polar regions through data interpretation. The featured investigation is called Data to the Rescue Penguins Need Our Help! (https://polar-ice.org/polar-explorer-adventures/data-to-the-rescue/) This module engages youth in exploration through data analysis and creatively communicating their understanding of polar science through a Data Jam. 

2. 4-H STEM Challenge: This national STEM Challenge, launched in August 2022, focuses on climate change. Polar content appears in all three activities including the Ocean Robot Test Tank, Ocean Expedition, and Ocean Communicator (https://4-h.org/parents/4-h-stem-challenge/). So far, 10,000 kits have been sold and the challenge is expected to reach approximately 300,000 youth. 

3. Arctic Mystery: In this six-part serial mystery (https://byrd.osu.edu/arctic-mystery), youth work to solve the disappearance of a researcher in Arctic Alaska through exploration of non-fiction readings and data sets. A facilitator guide and videos support implementation, and all materials are available on the project website. Youth are encouraged to build claims based on evidence and reasoning. 

4. Polar Puzzles: All seven Polar Puzzles (https://byrd.osu.edu/polar-puzzles), featuring researchers and their data in a style representative of a graphic novel, are available in print as kits and for download. Each puzzle includes a hand-on engagement activity, and the puzzles may be completed in any order. The kit includes a facilitator guide, answer booklet, and stickers.

5. Exploring Polar Science: More than 1,200 copies of this nationally peer-reviewed text have been sold online (https://extensionpubs.osu.edu/exploring-polar-science/) with additional digital copies distributed during the pandemic at no cost. The project book has been a judged youth event at county fairs and the Ohio State Fair since its release. 

An evaluation, conducted on a sample of 453 youth across 28 sites who participated in Polar Literacy programming found that: (1) Across program sites, participating youth reported high levels of engagement in science activities. (2) Across program sites, youth reported statistically significant increases in science identity. Gains were especially strong among youth who began the program with lower science identity scores. Youth who identified as URMs reported lower science identity than youth who did not identify as URMs. Importantly, however, youth who identified as URMs experienced gains in science identity from pre- program to post-program that were similar in magnitude to the gains made by youth who were not URMs. (3) Participating youth did not, as a group, report increases in fascination with science. However, youth with initially lower levels of fascination did show statistically significant gains from pre-program to post-program. (4) as a group, youth did not show significant increases in polar knowledge on a multiple- choice assessment, largely do to a misalignment of the evaluation instrument to the developing resources; (5) Across program sites, participating youth reported statistically significant increases in confidence in working with data. At the time of the project’s conclusion, one peer-reviewed manuscript had been published and two are in review. 

Early career polar researchers received professional development and were able to co-develop broader impact materials with the project team. Of the 80 researchers who engaged with the project team, approximately 25 were long-term engagements that developed customized materials. These materials were then shared with thousands of youth via OST programs over the five years of the project.

Rutgers University and The Ohio State University led this project with partners at the University of Colorado Boulder, The Franklin Institute, New Jersey 4-H, Ohio 4-H, Camp Oty’Okwa, and Science Education Resource Center at Carleton College. Additional OST providers participated over the life of the project. Education materials, media content, and professional knowledge/skills developed will outlast the project.
